bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 2, 1908

div1.p: Gorgas is convinced that mosquito eradication is the only method to keep yellow fever from developing into an epidemic.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 2, 1908
div1.opener:
Col. Gorgas letter
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
Copy
10
March, 2nd. 1908.
Major Jefferson R. Kean,
Adviser to the Sanitary Department,
Havana, Cuba.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
Yours of February 20th just received. I generally read
everything I can get hold of about you and your work in Cuba but
I had overlooked you letter in the Journal. I have just gotten
it out of our library and read your letter.

In your letter of transmittal you make a very clear statement
of the difficulties under which you labor. The greatest of
these, as far as Yellow Fever is concerned, seems to me the
wide spread character of the infection in the country districts,
and the large number of non-immunes with which you have to deal.

During my stay in Cuba I do not recollect that the fever
was at all spread, and there seemed to be none in the country
districts, or in the small towns or plantations. Toward the
latter part of 1901 the suburbs of Havana, Los Baños-Las-Vegas,
Santiago de las Vegas San Antonio de los Baños etc., became
pretty sharply infected. This was probably due to the fact that
the non-immune immigrants, who had been coming in since 1898 at
the rate of twenty thousand per year, were numerous enough
there to keep up the disease.

I have never been entirely prepared to accept the theory
that the inhabitant of an infected locality gets his immunity
because he had a light attack in childhood. It is a very
-2-
reasonable and plausible theory but I have never understood how,
if three or four thousand children were having Yellow Fever in
Havana every year, we could have gotten rid of it as we did in
1901.

My experience down here has lead me to believe that the
great and all important factor in fighting Yellow Fever is to decrease
the number of Stegomyia, and until you reduce the stegomyia below
a certain point Yellow Fever is bound to spread if introduced; and
that when you reduce them below a certain point, Yellow Fever will
not spread no matter how much it is introduced.

Now in 1901 when we commenced stegomyia work, we did so with
a well organized Department in which all that was necessary was
to give the order and the work went rapidly ahead. By September
we had gotten the stegomyia below the Yellow Fever point, and
though we were getting Yellow Fever cases in all the time from the
surrounding towns, it could not develop in Havana.

Now this may be the same with regard to children. When you
get the stegomyia below the Yellow Fever point, even if you are
having Yellow Fever among children at the rate of four or five
thousand cases per year; children will cease to have it.

When I left Havana I was inclined to think that the all
important point was isolation of the sick and the killing of the
infected mosquitoes. When we came down here, owing to the difficulties
in getting ourselves organized, getting supplies, want of support
from my superiors and constant and direct interference from them,
I was unable to get effective stegomyia work organized.

Owing to the fact that I looked upon the destruction of the
infected mosquitoes as the all important point, I concentrated
everything upon getting this branch of the work in an efficient
condition. From the beginning of 1905 the fumigation and isolation
of the sick was efficiently and thoroughly done, much more generally,
I think, that has ever been done anywhere else. The whole city
of Panama every house in it was fumigated three or four times, but
Yellow Fever did not begin to decline until the fall, and finally
disappeared in December 1905.

We got to work in Panama at systematic stegomyia work about
the first of March that year. Where you have a general infection
with infected mosquitoes all about the city, no system of fumigation
can kill them all. There must be a certain number everywhere that
escape death from fumigation in parts of buildings that cannot be
thoroughly fumigated, and these will always keep up the disease if
you rely upon fumigation alone. You can get rid of the stegomyia
with continuous and systematic work, but, it takes time.

I suppose that there is always the liability of a particular
house for a time getting above the Yellow Fever mark with its
stegomyia, and if a case happens to get into this house at this
time you would have a local infection, just as you would in a ship,
but such local infection would be easily controlled if your general
stegomyia work were good.

I believe that we now have on the Isthmus every where the
stegomyia below the Yellow Fever mark, and that we could drop our
-4-
quarantines and let Yellow Fever in freely without any spread of
the disease. Havana, too, I presume is in this condition.

In 1901 we admitted into Havana from infected points some
twelve hundred non-immunes under observation, and picked up from
these non-immunes some thirty or forty cases of Yellow Fever. The
only explanation I can give as to why the disease was not kept up
by this importation is the fact that the stegomyia were below the
Yellow Fever point. There must have been many mild cases among
so many non-immunes that we did not get hold of. This is the
Gorgas theory of the spread of Yellow Fever.

I am inclined to think now that if you and I took two cities
of the same size, of same general conditions, and you went into
one and put in vogue all our present methods, and I went into
the other and did not do a bit of fumigation, isolating the sick,
or have a quarantine, did nothing but stegomyia work, I would get
rid of the Yellow Fever as soon as you would, or possibly a little
sooner, as I would probably devote more attention to the stegomyia
work that you would.

On the other hand, if you did no stegomyia work or did it
so imperfectly that the stegomyia would remain above the Yellow
Fever mark, you would never get rid of Yellow Fever if you
worked at it a life-time, granting that these cities were in the
Tropics as Panama is.

You speak of using canvas more and more in your fumigations.
I presume you mean in fumigating huts, and buildings of that kind,
-5-
and that you draw the canvas over the entire building. We use
manilla paper, generally, for closing windows and doors; canvas
might be cheaper for this purpose as you could use it so many
times. Paper cannot in general be used more than once.

I look upon pyrethrum as one of the best insecticides in
municipal fumigating. It is so much less hurtful to the contents
of the building, than is sulphur, and I would rather use a less
efficient material and have the co-operation of the people concerned
than to use amore effective insecticide and get their opposition.

We went into the question of the efficiency of pyrethrum in
our laboratory here quite extensively and found that when pyre-
thrum was carefully selected it answered our purposes very well.
I do not recollect Dr. Thomas' proofpaper here with regard to pyrethrum;
he probably convinced himself but not us.

We use toward the latter part of our fumigations a carbolic-
camphor mixture, which is a very fatal insecticide, more so that
pyrethrum, but it is very inflammable. I think however that in
future fumigations, I would depend upon the carbolic -camphor
mixture for fumigating the better class of houses rather than
pyrethrum.

We finally insisted upon getting only the Parke, Davis Company
insect powder. The pyrethrum bought in the open market was
found to be unreliable.

I understand what a very hard proposition you have had to
tackle with the whole island full of non-immunes and foci of
-6-
Yellow Fever all over the country districts. But so much more the
glory when you lay aside your shield and spear and take your
“otium cum dignatate”.

Your great work in Cuba, it seems to me, will be the sanitary
organization which you have built up. It is unique, and as far as
I know, there is no such organization anywhere else, where the
national and municipal sanitation are brought together, the
maritime quarantines and public charities, all in one department,
and the Head of the Department a Member of the Cabinet. I presume
this is due to your eloquence with Magoon, for when he left here
his ideas were entirely in the other direction.

The liberties with your name were taken by the Washington
Office and not by ourselves. We know you better, they hear of
you probably only through your relentless persecution of the poor
Cubana and, therefore, think it ought to be rather Jackson than
Jefferson.

Mrs. Gorgas joins me in kindest regards to both your-
self and Mrs. Kean.
